items.title: sparql snipet -  - Scrapbox
items.content:
https://github.com/lodac/lodac/wiki/SPARQL



 
  

code:Ikuno.rq
 prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
 prefix xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
 prefix netkeiba: <https://db.netkeiba.com/>
 prefix horse: <https://db.netkeiba.com/horse/>
 prefix trainer: <https://db.netkeiba.com/trainer/>
 prefix owner: <https://db.netkeiba.com/owner/>
 prefix breeder: <https://db.netkeiba.com/breeder/>
 
 prefix relation: <https://db.netkeiba.com/horse/ped#>
 prefix race: <https://db.netkeiba.com/race/>
 
 select ?race
 where {
   horse:1987104784 horse:race_history/rdf:rest*/rdf:first ?race .
 }


code:all_graph
 # endpoint
 SELECT DISTINCT ?g
 WHERE {
   GRAPH ?g {?s ?p ?o}
 }
 ORDER BY ?g



NumberOfBuffers = 160000
MaxDirtyBuffers = 120000
rdf_loader_run() * 1;
horse 151993 ms race 1810889 ms 30
 CPU
code:ls -lah
 total 1.7G
 drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4.0K Oct 27 15:45 .
 drwxr-xr-x 10 kiai kiai 4.0K Oct 27 15:43 ..
 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 6.0M Oct 27 15:49 virtuoso-temp.db
 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1.7G Oct 27 16:15 virtuoso.db

 urn:activitystreams-owl:map
 http://localhost:8890/sparql
 http://localhost:8890/DAV/
 http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#
GUI
items.contentSnippet:
https://github.com/lodac/lodac/wiki/SPARQL




code:Ikuno.rq
prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
prefix xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#> 
prefix netkeiba: <https://db.netkeiba.com/> 
prefix horse: <https://db.netkeiba.com/horse/> 
prefix trainer: <https://db.netkeiba.com/trainer/> 
prefix owner: <https://db.netkeiba.com/owner/> 
prefix breeder: <https://db.netkeiba.com/breeder/> 

prefix relation: <https://db.netkeiba.com/horse/ped#>
prefix race: <https://db.netkeiba.com/race/> 

select ?race
where { 
horse:1987104784 horse:race_history/rdf:rest*/rdf:first ?race .
}

code:all_graph
# endpoint 
SELECT DISTINCT ?g 
WHERE { 
GRAPH ?g {?s ?p ?o}
}
ORDER BY ?g


NumberOfBuffers = 160000
MaxDirtyBuffers   = 120000
rdf_loader_run() * 1;
horse 151993 ms race 1810889 ms 30 
CPU
code:ls -lah
total 1.7G
drwxr-xr-x  2 root root 4.0K Oct 27 15:45 .
drwxr-xr-x 10 kiai kiai 4.0K Oct 27 15:43 ..
-rw-r--r--  1 root root 6.0M Oct 27 15:49 virtuoso-temp.db
-rw-r--r--  1 root root 1.7G Oct 27 16:15 virtuoso.db
urn:activitystreams-owl:map	
http://localhost:8890/sparql	
http://localhost:8890/DAV/
http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#
GUI

items.title: Container-Optimized OS -  - Scrapbox
items.content:
#GCE #GCP

GCP Container-Optimized OS tips | gotohayato.com

cloud-config user-data 256KB
 

startup-script startup-script-url
 

cf. GCE startup/shutdown script - Qiita


Docker Compose

a) Custom metadata user-data daemon
b) Custom metadata startup-script

cloud-init
startup-script startup-script-url GCS
 cloud-init start-up

/home/username/myapp/ docker-compose.yml docker-compose up -d

/home/username/myapp/ gsutil GCS

VM metadata ENV_FILE .env startup-script.env

items.title: Step 4. Install and generate Prisma Client -  - Scrapbox
items.content:
code:terminal
 $ npm install @prisma/client
 $ npx prisma generate

Prisma ClientPrismanpx prisma generate

code:terminal
 $ mkdir lib && touch lib/prisma.ts

prisma.ts prisma lib

code:lib/prisma.ts
 // lib/prisma.ts
 import { PrismaClient } from '@prisma/client';
 
 let prisma: PrismaClient;
 
 if (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production') {
   prisma = new PrismaClient();
 } else {
   if (!global.prisma) {
     global.prisma = new PrismaClient();
   }
   prisma = global.prisma;
 }
 
 export default prisma;

Step 5. Update the existing views to load data from the database

items.title: Step 3. Create your database schema with Prisma -  - Scrapbox
items.content:
code:schema.prisma
 // schema.prisma
 datasource db {
   provider = "postgresql"
   url = env("DATABASE_URL")
 }
 
 generator client {
   provider = "prisma-client-js"
 }
 
 model Post {
   id Int @default(autoincrement()) @id
   title String
   content String?
   published Boolean @default(false)
   author User? @relation(fields: authorId, references: id)
   authorId Int?
 }
 
 model User {
   id Int @default(autoincrement()) @id
   name String?
   email String? @unique
   createdAt DateTime @default(now()) @map(name: "created_at")
   updatedAt DateTime @updatedAt @map(name: "updated_at")
   posts Post[]
   @@map(name: "users")
 }


This Prisma schema defines two models, each of which will map to a table in the underlying database: User and Post. Notice that there's also a relation (one-to-many) between the two models, via the author field on Post and the posts field on User.

User Post

code:terminal
 $ npx prisma db push

PostgreSQL

code:terminal
 $ npx prisma studio

ORM
Next.js

Step 4. Install and generate Prisma Client
items.contentSnippet:
code:schema.prisma
// schema.prisma
datasource db {
provider = "postgresql"
url      = env("DATABASE_URL")
}

generator client {
provider = "prisma-client-js"
}

model Post {
id        Int     @default(autoincrement()) @id
title     String
content   String?
published Boolean @default(false)
author    User?   @relation(fields: authorId, references: id)
authorId  Int?
}

model User {
id            Int       @default(autoincrement()) @id
name          String?
email         String?   @unique
createdAt     DateTime  @default(now()) @map(name: "created_at")
updatedAt     DateTime  @updatedAt @map(name: "updated_at")
posts         Post[]
@@map(name: "users")
}

This Prisma schema defines two models, each of which will map to a table in the underlying database: User and Post. Notice that there's also a relation (one-to-many) between the two models, via the author field on Post and the posts field on User.
User  Post 
code:terminal
$ npx prisma db push
PostgreSQL 
code:terminal
$ npx prisma studio
ORM
 Next.js 
Step 4. Install and generate Prisma Client

items.title: Creating a Custom Dataset for your files -  - Scrapbox
items.content:
#pytorch

A custom Dataset class must implement three functions: __init__, __len__, and __getitem__.

__init__, __len__, __getitem__
https://pytorch.org/tutorials/beginner/basics/data_tutorial.html#creating-a-custom-dataset-for-your-files

__init__
The __init__ function is run once when instantiating the Dataset object.

__init__()Dataset

__len__
The __len__ function returns the number of samples in our dataset.



__getitem__
The __getitem__ function loads and returns a sample from the dataset at the given index idx. Based on the index, it identifies the images location on disk, converts that to a tensor using read_image, retrieves the corresponding label from the csv data in self.img_labels, calls the transform functions on them (if applicable), and returns the tensor image and corresponding label in a tuple.

__getitem__() idx
 idx



 pytorch
items.contentSnippet:
#pytorch
A custom Dataset class must implement three functions: __init__, __len__, and __getitem__. 
__init__, __len__, __getitem__ 
https://pytorch.org/tutorials/beginner/basics/data_tutorial.html#creating-a-custom-dataset-for-your-files
__init__
The __init__ function is run once when instantiating the Dataset object. 
__init__()Dataset 
__len__
The __len__ function returns the number of samples in our dataset.

__getitem__
The __getitem__ function loads and returns a sample from the dataset at the given index idx. Based on the index, it identifies the images location on disk, converts that to a tensor using read_image, retrieves the corresponding label from the csv data in self.img_labels, calls the transform functions on them (if applicable), and returns the tensor image and corresponding label in a tuple.
__getitem__()  idx
idx
